metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Sidaoqiao Superstation, 2014)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the data of the meteorological element gradient observation system of the Sidaoqiao superstation downstream of the Heihe Hydrometeorological Observation Network from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2014. The site is located in Sidaoqiao, Dalaihu Town, Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia. The underlying surface is Tamarix. The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 101.1374E, 42.0012N, and the altitude is 873m. The air temperature, relative humidity and wind speed sensors are respectively set at 5m, 7m, 10m, 15m, 20m and 28m, with 6 layers facing the north; the wind direction sensor is set at 15m, facing the north; the barometer is installed in the waterproof box. The tipping bucket rain gauge is installed at 28m; the four-component radiometer is installed at 10m, facing south; two infrared thermometers are installed at 10m, facing south, the probe orientation is vertically downward; two photosynthetically active radiometers are installed At 10m, facing south, and the probe is vertically upward and downward respectively; the soil moisture sensor is installed 2m on the south side of the tower body, and the soil heat flow plates (self-correcting type) (3 pieces) are buried in turn in the ground 6cm deep; The average soil temperature sensor TCAV is buried in the ground 2cm, 4cm; the soil temperature probe is buried in the ground surface 0cm and underground 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm; soil moisture sensors are buried in the underground 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm.
Observed items include: wind speed (WS_5m, WS_7m, WS_10m, WS_15m, WS_20m, WS_28m) (unit: m/s), wind direction (WD_15m) (unit: degree), air temperature and humidity (Ta_5m, Ta_7m, Ta_10m, Ta_15m, Ta_20m, Ta_28m and RH_5m, RH_7m, RH_10m, RH_15m, RH_20m, RH_28m) (unit: centigrade, percentage), pressure (unit: hectopascal), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), four-component radiation (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts/square meter), surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit: centigrade), up and down photosynthetically active radiation (PAR_U_up, PAR_U_down) (unit: micromol/square Msec), average soil temperature (TCAV) (unit: centigrade), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (unit: watts/square meter), soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_80cm) , Ms_120cm, Ms_160cm) (unit: volumetric water content, percentage), soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_120cm, Ts_160cm) (unit: centigrade).
Processing and quality control of the observation data: (1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10 minutes), when there is missing data, it is marked by -6999; From September 8, 2014 to November 8, due to the sensor problems, the data is missing; on May 9, 2014, the soil moisture probe was re-buried, and the data before and after is inconsistent; (2) eliminate the moment with duplicate records; (3) delete the data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument; (5) the format of date and time is uniform, and the date and time are in the same column. For example, the time is: 2014-9-10 10:30; (6) the naming rules are: AWS+ site name.
For hydrometeorological network or site information, please refer to Li et al. (2013). For observation data processing, please refer to Liu et al. (2011).

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Are there challenges in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems due to ecological environment degradation?
Is it possible to obtain long-term datasets for hydrometeorological and flux measurements in oasis–desert systems?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection method is more suitable for measuring soil heat flux in arid regions: using a series TSEB model with ground measurement or employing a scintillometer?
Disjunctive.Answer: using a series TSEB model with ground measurement

Concept Completion.Question: What types of sensors are used in the meteorological observation systems for data collection in this domain?
Concept Completion.Answer: Air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed sensors, wind direction sensors, barometers, tipping bucket rain gauges, four-component radiometers, infrared thermometers, photosynthetically active radiation sensors, soil sensors, soil heat flux plates, average soil temperature sensors (TCAV), soil temperature probes, soil moisture sensors

Concept Completion.Question: When is data typically collected in the meteorological observation systems for this field?
Where are the meteorological observation sites typically located in this field?

Example.Question: What is an example of a data quality control technique used in handling hydrometeorological datasets?
Example.Answer: An example of a data quality control technique is the process of ensuring data completeness by marking missing data with specific codes (e.g., -6999 for missing values), removing duplicate records, and eliminating data points that appear to exceed physical or instrumental limits, as well as flagging questionable data using color codes for further review.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the data collection methods used for observing meteorological parameters in arid and semiarid regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: automatic weather stations, air temperature, wind speed, humidity, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, turbulent fluxes

Quantification.Question: What is the frequency of data collection for meteorological parameters in the hydrometeorological observation network?
How many layers of air temperature and relative humidity sensors are used in the meteorological gradient observation system?

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of hydrometeorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: An 'eddy covariance system' refers to a measurement technique used to quantify turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and other gases between the land surface and the atmosphere. This system typically involves the use of high-frequency sensors to capture vertical wind speeds and scalar concentrations, allowing for the calculation of fluxes based on the covariance between these variables. In the context of hydrometeorological data collection, it provides half-hourly turbulent flux data as part of a comprehensive suite of observational datasets.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges faced in data collection for energy balance models in arid agricultural areas versus oasis-desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: In arid agricultural areas, challenges include accurately estimating surface fluxes due to strong advective environments and incomplete energy balance closure in EC flux measurements. In contrast, oasis-desert ecosystems face challenges such as ecological degradation and maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems, which require long-term data collection for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Both environments require advanced methodologies to address these specific challenges.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations enhance the understanding of evapotranspiration processes in arid and semi-arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with ground-based observations provides a more comprehensive view of evapotranspiration processes by combining high-resolution spatial data with detailed temporal measurements. Remote sensing can cover larger areas and offer insights into regional patterns, while ground-based data provide precise local measurements, allowing for validation and calibration of models. This combination is particularly useful in capturing the spatial heterogeneity and temporal dynamics of water and energy exchanges in arid and semi-arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have led to the necessity of complex data collection systems in hydrometeorological observations, particularly in the context of oasis–desert interactions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for complex data collection systems in hydrometeorological observations, especially in oasis–desert interactions, stems from the necessity to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange dynamics. This understanding is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and achieving sustainable development goals in arid and semi-arid regions. The unique ecological landscape of oases, which supports a significant population, necessitates detailed observations to manage water resources and ecological security effectively.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to account for errors in component temperature estimations when using models for evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accounting for errors in component temperature estimations is crucial because inaccuracies can significantly affect the performance of models like the TSEB model, which are used for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes. Errors primarily arise from image classification inaccuracies and other factors such as atmospheric radiation, which can lead to overestimations of component temperatures, thereby impacting the reliability of evapotranspiration estimates.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for the challenges faced in data collection in arid and semi-arid regions, particularly regarding the degradation of natural environments?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in data collection in arid and semi-arid regions, such as the degradation of natural environments, are influenced by factors like the drying up of rivers, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are exacerbated by climate change and human activities, which impact the ecological balance and complicate the collection and accuracy of environmental data necessary for managing these fragile ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using high-resolution thermal cameras in data collection for estimating evapotranspiration in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-resolution thermal cameras allows for more accurate separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures, which can improve the estimation of evapotranspiration by providing reliable estimates of latent heat fluxes. This results in better validation of evaporation and transpiration ratios, even in strongly advective conditions, as shown by the TSEB model's performance when validated against ground-based measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers in data collection impact the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers provides high-frequency, half-hourly data on turbulent fluxes, enhancing the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. These instruments help in capturing the dynamics of these exchanges, supporting the goal of achieving sustainable oasis development by providing critical insights into the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of long-term observational datasets from oasis-desert systems for carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets provide a quantitative understanding of the interactions between energy, water vapor, and carbon in oasis-desert systems, which is crucial for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality. These datasets offer insights into the ecological and socioeconomic impacts, aiding in the development of strategies to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems and support sustainable development goals.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate aim of establishing a hydrometeorological observation network in a specific ecological region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of establishing a hydrometeorological observation network is to collect comprehensive data on meteorological and soil parameters to understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes in oasis-desert ecosystems. This understanding is crucial for achieving sustainable development and maintaining ecological balance in arid and semi-arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to ensure the quality control of meteorological and hydrological data collected from a superstation in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The quality control procedures include ensuring daily data integrity with 144 data points every 10 minutes, marking missing data with a specific placeholder, and removing duplicates. Data that fall outside physical or instrument limits are deleted, and questionable data are highlighted for review. Consistent formatting for date and time is also maintained.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are soil and canopy component temperatures derived and validated for evaluating energy balance models in agricultural settings?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are derived using a thermal infrared camera, with images classified into soil and canopy pixels. The directional brightness temperatures are extracted and converted to radiation temperatures using long-wave radiation observations and emissivities. These temperatures are validated against surface radiometric temperatures calculated from four-component radiometer observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in setting up and collecting data from an eddy covariance system to measure energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The setup includes installing an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for half-hourly turbulent flux data collection. Automatic weather stations measure various hydrometeorological parameters with a 10-minute average period. Vegetation and soil parameters are also recorded. Data processing involves collection, quality control, and archiving and sharing for further analysis.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the precise measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution thermal cameras, such as the Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera, enables the precise measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures. These cameras are used to capture thermal radiation images, which are then processed to obtain radiometric temperatures for soil and canopy components.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the effective separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures in the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model?
Enablement.Answer: The effective separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures in the TSEB model is enabled by using thermal images to classify soil and canopy pixels and calculate directional brightness temperatures. The methodology involves converting thermal infrared temperatures to radiation temperatures using long-wave radiation data and emissivities, which allows for accurate temperature separation and subsequent energy balance calculations.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, and why might traditional data collection methods struggle to address these?
Expectation.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure when using EC flux measurements of H and LE. Traditional data collection methods might struggle because the uncertainty in surface-air temperature difference can dominate, and errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures can affect the model's performance.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be an expectation that certain parameters and observations required for evapotranspiration models cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data?
Expectation.Answer: Certain parameters and observations required for evapotranspiration models may not be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data because the models, such as the Shuttleworth and Wallace two-source evapotranspiration model, are complex and involve multiple resistances that are difficult to calculate. Additionally, the necessary input data for these models is often not available from conventional observation systems.

Expectation.Question: What expectations exist regarding the effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions, and what factors contribute to these expectations?
Expectation.Answer: The effectiveness of composite temperature separation approaches in arid regions is expected to be limited. This limitation arises because errors in the derived component temperature are primarily caused by image classification errors, which vary with vegetation abundance. Additionally, uncertainties in atmospheric upwelling radiation, transmittance, and estimated incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy contribute to these expectations.

Judgmental.Question: How do researchers evaluate the effectiveness of data collection methods for capturing accurate soil and canopy temperatures in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: Researchers utilize ground-based measurement data, such as those obtained from high-resolution thermal cameras, to accurately assess soil and canopy temperatures. These temperatures are crucial for partitioning evapotranspiration into its components, and the effectiveness is evaluated by comparing the derived temperatures against observed values, ensuring they align with the energy balance equations used in the TSEB model.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do researchers face when ensuring the quality and continuity of hydrometeorological data in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges include dealing with data loss due to sensor issues, such as missing soil heat flux data, and ensuring that data is not duplicated or contains values beyond physical or instrumental limits. Quality control involves flagging questionable data, standardizing formats, and addressing gaps, such as those caused by reinstallation or malfunctioning of sensors, to maintain a continuous and reliable dataset.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can datasets from oasis-desert systems contribute to understanding the ecological interactions in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Datasets from oasis-desert systems provide insights into long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, which are vital for understanding ecological interactions. These datasets help explore the balance between oasis and desert systems, contributing to sustainable development goals by offering quantitative data on how these systems interact and affect the overall ecological stability and productivity of arid regions.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how data collection techniques can ensure accuracy in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems.
Assertion.Answer: In oasis–desert systems, accuracy in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange is ensured through the use of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations measuring radiation, soil heat flux, and other hydrometeorological parameters. These methods are supplemented with vegetation and soil parameter data for comprehensive analysis.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting reliable data for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes.
Assertion.Answer: Collecting reliable data for estimating evapotranspiration in heterogeneous landscapes is challenging due to the need to accurately separate soil and canopy temperatures. Errors can arise from image classification inaccuracies and uncertainties in radiation transmittance through the canopy, affecting the estimation of surface fluxes.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets on soil characteristics can be effectively integrated with meteorological data for comprehensive ecological studies.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets on soil characteristics, such as soil temperature and moisture profiles, are integrated with meteorological data by installing sensors at various depths and using automatic weather stations to collect data on air temperature, humidity, and other parameters. This integration allows for a detailed understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon dynamics in ecological studies.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used in hydrometeorological observations within the oasis–desert systems from 2012 to 2021, highlighting the type of equipment and frequency of data collection.
Request/Directive.Answer: The hydrometeorological data in oasis–desert systems were collected using automatic weather stations and included measurements of radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles. These observations were recorded with a 10-minute average period, and additional data were acquired using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas using the TSEB model.
Request/Directive.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure in EC flux measurements and errors in determining surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures. The strong advective environment and image classification errors also contribute to the uncertainty in model performance, affecting the separation of soil and vegetation component temperatures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the potential sources and strategies for expanding datasets related to energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, researchers could enhance long-term observational datasets by integrating data from additional land surface flux and meteorological stations. These datasets could include detailed hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, and involve data collection from both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, as seen in the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin.
